topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Casey opens with a critique of overly rigid PM frameworks, and Lenny introduces Casey’s background and what the episode will cover.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Amplitude and Eppo, focused on analytics and experimentation tooling for product and growth teams.

topics.title: Casey’s current work and advising
topics.summary: Casey shares what he’s doing post-Eventbrite: advising (Whatnot, Eventbrite), board work, angel investing, and revamping Reforge’s product strategy program.

topics.title: Why the CPO role is so hard
topics.summary: Casey explains why CPO tenure is often short: shifting business needs, CEO alignment risk, and executive-level accountability without “PIPs,” plus why he transitioned out of the role.

topics.title: How to survive and succeed as CPO
topics.summary: Key lessons: be a company executive first, build credibility across functions, and explicitly diagnose team/product strengths and gaps while educating peers on what “great product” looks like.

topics.title: Zero interest rate phenomenon product managers
topics.summary: Casey describes how abundant capital led PMs to over-index on process, research, and “best practices,” reducing risk-taking and decision-making under uncertainty—especially problematic in startups.

topics.title: When to use research vs ship to learn
topics.summary: Casey gives heuristics for research allocation: consumer products should bias toward shipping/experimentation; enterprise relies more on direct customer input; “middle” businesses must reserve research for high-uncertainty, high-leverage problems.

topics.title: Whatnot overview and interviewing PMs
topics.summary: Casey explains Whatnot (live-streaming collectibles marketplace) and shares an interview philosophy focused on realistic scenarios over performative storytelling, plus red flags like slow-to-signal solutions.

topics.title: AI and the future of product management
topics.summary: Casey argues PMs won’t be replaced if they do real decision-making; he warns current AI can be confidently wrong, but is useful for low-risk tasks like formulas, tooling steps, and automation help.

topics.title: Founder intuition versus team expertise
topics.summary: Casey outlines how founders should initially direct decisions due to deep product intuition, then delegate as teams build expertise; employees should signal when they need direction or when they’ve earned trust to own decisions.

topics.title: Influencing founders and handling disagreement
topics.summary: Advice for pushing back: learn what evidence a founder responds to (data, advisors, customers), build the case accordingly, and if still overruled, disagree-and-commit or move on; Casey shares how he used external validation at Pinterest.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Ahrefs Webmaster Tools, highlighting free SEO audits, backlink insights, and keyword visibility tracking.

topics.title: Network effects: types and how they evolve
topics.summary: Casey defines network effects and breaks down direct, cross-side, and data network effects, explaining why many products (especially social) evolve beyond pure direct effects to monetize and personalize.

topics.title: Marketplace examples and Grubhub disruption setup
topics.summary: Casey discusses examples like Zillow and begins explaining how marketplaces with network effects can still be disrupted—often when competitors expand selection via new supply strategies like building delivery networks.
